case_vignette: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 4-day history of painful lesions in his mouth. During the past year, he has twice had similar lesions that resolved without treatment after approximately 10 days. He has never had any genital or anal lesions. His mother reports that he has been very stressed over the past month because he is approaching his senior year at high school. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. He appears thin. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). A photograph of his oral cavity is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've had painful sores in my mouth for the past 4 days.
Have you had a fever recently?
I have a slight fever at 37.6°C (99.7°F).
Do you have any rashes or lesions on your skin?
No, I don't have any rashes or lesions on my skin.
Do you have a history of any autoimmune diseases?
I am otherwise healthy and have no history of autoimmune diseases.
Are you currently taking any medications?
No, I'm not taking any medications.
Do you have a family history of similar symptoms or conditions?
I don't know, nobody has told me about any family history of similar symptoms.
**Final Diagnosis:** Aphthous stomatitis
